1) I assume you mean ones that are not in the database?  You can use the rebar-join script from the node or outside it if you have SSH access.  You can also use the API/CLI to create the nodes in advance so they are pre-identified when they show up.
2) <@U02DJQSG8> may have better idea.  I think that can be handled by profiles where the attribs are different in each profile
3) that's another question <@U02DJQSG8> but I believe yes.

2) There are a couple of different ways to handle that.  Quickest is to have a new bootenv and a new seed template.
Most flexible is to abstract the partitioning stuff out into a per-node attrib, and expand that in the template.

2) There are a couple of different ways to handle that.  Quickest is to have a new bootenv and a new seed template.
Most flexible is to abstract the partitioning stuff out into a per-node attrib, and expand that in the template.
3) Not as of yet, no.  It is a good ask, tho -- the Go text/template language allows for such things, but I would need a reasonable way to expose that functionality.
@mech422 I have not messed with freebsd in... a long time.  The last time I tried playing around with any of the *bsds was approx. NetBSD 1.5.
That said, if there is a way to do an unattended install the uses PXE and does not use NFS, we can probably handle it.
